description:
A learned 17th-century coinage, mono- +‎ theism, from (μονός (monós, “one”)) and (θεός (theós, “god, deity”) + -ισμός (-ismós)) The term parallels the earlier polytheism, atheism (the simplex theism being slightly later).
The earliest known use is by Henry More, ca. 1660, in explicit juxtaposition with both atheism and polytheism.

entries.meaning: The belief in a single deity (one god or goddess); especially within an organized religion.
The belief that God is one person (Judaism, Christianity, Islam), not three persons (Trinitarianism, Hinduism)
